chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: In January 2005 I wrote the first version of freeVikings, and, very proud of my first game (it was funless, boring, often crashing), published it on the Internet. A lot has changed since January 2005. I'm not so proud of my first game. And, I think, it's never more funless.

FreeVikings now have several fancy features you expect a good game to have. It's usually stable, good-looking
This is a joke. Actually, freeVikings are still awful. I'm not able to do anything with this. and extendable.

When the developers make their application scriptable, they don't usually do it for themselves but for the users. Or they say they are doing it for users (everybody knows that the software developers only do things for fun). FreeVikings are scriptable. It means...
Yes, you're right. Actually it means I was playing with Ruby. But forget it, will you? It means I want to give you the possibility of extending freeVikings with your own levels. You can catch Erik, Baleog and Olaf into your own traps. It seems good, doesn't it?
So if you like freeVikings, have just a small amount of time for playing around a bit, ... Go on reading and make the best freeVikings level ever seen.

chapter.title: First map
chapter.para: This chapter will guide you through the first steps of the freeVikings level developer. You will start with clean hands and end with a ready to use map.

section.title: Requirements
section.para:
What do you need? At least you need a computer with a running
At first I wrote "well running". Then I looked at the text I had just written. FreeVikings do never run well... And I retyped the sentence quickly. freeVikings installation and some plain text editor. If I could recommend you some, I would tell you to choose GNU Emacs (because I like this great beast), but any editor with XML syntax highlighting is good enough for our purpose and you can, if you are some kind of fanatic, use ed od NotePad.

sidebar.title: Text-editing fanatism
sidebar.para: Just a word on text-editing fanatism. I think you know some of the strange W!ndows users who say "NotePad forever!" and "Anyone who doesn't write web pages in NotePad isn't a programmer". What do they find so good on an editor which tries to save every file with suffix .txt unless you click two times more than you want?

On they other hand I have heard about some old Un!x hackers who hesitate to use any other text editor than ancient ed. I don't understand them either but I think they feel some kind of nostalgy using the pure line-editing stuff.

section.para: Another good thig to install on your computer is Tiled, a Java-written tile map editor. It allows you to develop maps quickly (and gives you more time for a much more interesting activity - scripting :o) ).

Tiled produces simple but full-featured human-readable map files in XML format. Maybe you know (but I don't think so) freeVikings have a native map format which is also subset of XML language (I like XML very much since I've first learned about it). Support for Tiled maps was added experimentally in release 0.5 because I think possibility of creating maps in visual way will encourage people to create and share new levels.

Just one more application. Some graphic editor for creating all kinds of graphics. I personally use GIMP. It has a lot of interesting features, is scriptable (do you know Scheme? Don't you? It's fun!) and free (it means poor people don't have to download it from warez servers and you can download and read the whole source code if you want). You will need some graphic editor to make your own tilesets (those distributed with freeVikings aren't still any good) and maybe your own creatures to make the new levels more interesting.
